value: Palacio de Gobierno (Nuevo Leon State House), now used as a state museum.
- Mexico's third-biggest city and capital of Nuevo Leon.
- Small city in the heart of Nuevo León's orange-growing belt.
- City between two rivers, with some interesting colonial buildings. Good place to buy
- One of the smallest municipalities of Nuevo Leon, the " Templo de la Advocación de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe" is their biggest attraction.
- Founded in the XVII century, the main plazs is one of the best places to hang around.
- Mexico's largest national park. Rugged canyons and gorges in the Sierra Madre Orientals.
- Is home to one of the unique archaeological sites in Northeast Mexico. These are numerous stone carvings, isolated from any populated area, being deep within the semidesertic area.
- If you are fanatic of extreme sports, this a place to be. Is famous for its abundant rivers, waterfalls and underground caves. Is advised to get proper equipment.

Spanish is the official language. English is widely taught as a second language. People will speak it in various levels, but within the Metropolitan area of Monterrey is were most likely fluent speakers will be found.
Car, bus, plane, and 18-wheeler are the most common ways to get to Nuevo Leon.

value: : Nuevo Leon has one checkpoint on the U.S./Mexico border, it is the Colombia Bridge just west of
. Highway 85 south of Nuevo Laredo enters the state of Nuevo Leon about 20 miles south of the border.
: Most people in the region use buses heavily. Monterrey is the major hub.

People usually get around by bus, that goes to almost every place in the whole state, you can also use the subway, the taxi, or if you prefer to, you can walk to your destination

value: - Lying just 30 minutes out of Monterrey is a delightful underground world. The caverns are reached by riding a cable car to the cave entrance where guides lead visitors on a mile-long trek through the cave system. From Monterrey, take Mexico route 40 toward Saltillo.

There is a lot of stuff to do in NL, like:

value: Museums: In the whole state there are more than 30 museums, some of them are:

(Museum of contemporary art): The museum its located to a side of the government hall, it has always a different exhibition of contemporary latinoamerican images.
(Planetary Alfa) : Its one of the best museums of technology, art and science, it counts with interactives exhibitions, a big observatory and an IMAX screen, where they have documentals every week.

(Museum of Mexican History): The museum counts the history of the state and the country since the prehistory, it has 1 permanent exposition in the 2 floor and in the 1 floor there it is a different exposition.

often set up checkpoints on highways. They are looking for drug traffickers, but they will occasionally ask to see your tourist permits or vehicle import permits. They are usually efficient and quick, and chances are good that if you look like tourists, you'll simply be waved on.
